data.text: Testicular Pain from Bicycle Saddle

Odd question‚Ä¶ anyone get testicular pain from saddle or shorts. It‚Äôs just odd got a new supersix evo se, been riding but have been getting serious pain even after 10-20 mile ride. You know start over analyzing is Saddle to far back or forward, is it digging in to back of testicles‚Ä¶.. and so on. Been cycling about 10 years and never had this issue. I am sure bike fit will be first thing said but went to shop and had all measurements set up same as old bike. Any broad ideas I would appreciate the input. Thanks.

A more upright riding position might help. Also, some saddles have a sort of groove down the middle designed to take pressure off the sensitive areas. More upright combined with the seat placed pretty far back (paradoxically) works for me. But man, saddle pain is so personal just keep doing the trail and error and hopefully you‚Äôll find something that‚Äôll work. Last resort there‚Äôs always the recumbent bicycle (not the stationary kind).
data.author: Joost Verboven

data.text: Only on the MTB when I mess up a landing and punch my nads with my saddle ü§£
data.author: Kent Hutchins

data.text: My experience would be with a saddle slightly nosed up too much. If all your measurements match old bike a different saddle profile may just need to be nosed down slightly
data.author: Neil Wortley

data.text: Are you on the stock saddle or one that you normally ride?
data.author: Art Pelham

data.text: You should absolutely see a physician.
data.author: Brent Davis

data.text: Get an SMP saddle. Looks odd but works.
data.author: Jock DeBoer

data.text: I agree. It is harder than most to find the perfect angle.
data.author: Curtis Johnson

data.text: I went from the Pro to the plus and recently switched to the TRK. I think I finally found the perfect saddle. ÔøºÔøº
data.author: Jock DeBoer

data.text: I have the Dracon and a Pro. My butt seem to like a slight change every few years.
data.author: Curtis Johnson

data.text: You need a new bike. ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è All joking aside, see a doctor (as interesting as the internet answers are). I had testicular pain that turned out to be a cancerous tumour.
data.author: Rob Davies

data.text: A few years back I started having the same pain(~53).Started worrying about cancer our some other serious problem. Doctor asked how much I was riding a week at the end of the exam. When I told him 150+, told me to cut back and give them a rest. Soreness went away. Changing saddles can also help. Ask fellow riders if they have saddles they will loan you to test ride. I started our group to share a saddle ‚ÄúLibrary‚Äù.
data.author: Curtis Johnson

data.text: same seat? if not maybe start there.
data.author: Chris Summers

data.text: On a ride that short, assuming you weren't previously having pain, it's going to be coming from your saddle... could be shape, width, fore/aft position, or angle. Get a proper bike fit, including having your sit bones and flexibility measured. Sit bone width will tell you the proper saddle width for your physiology and flexibility will point you toward the proper saddle shape for your physiology... from there, a competent bike fitter will help you get the angle dialed in. Each bike is different so just copying the measurements doesn't work unless you're using something like a Retul imaging system.
data.author: Troy Browning

data.text: On your next physical---check your PSA ---if the numbers are elevated take care of it ASAP ! Had my surgery a year ago last feb . I'm 81 and have been riding many years .
data.author: Larry Hipskind

data.text: Yes, and before then I'd check that the *old* bike doesn't *also* cause this pain. In other words, was it the bike change, or did *you* change.
data.author: Mark Janeba

data.text: appreciate it. Went and saw physician, did ultrasound and ram psa all good
data.author: Joe Heckman

data.text: If the pain is severe enough then definitely see a Doctor. Testicular Torsion is no joke.
data.author: Kyle Weston

data.text: did no torsion, that‚Äôs what the urologist said it‚Äôs horrible and you only have limited time to get it taken care of
data.author: Joe Heckman

data.text: it definitely is. My college roommate had it and thank God I was able to him to the hospital in time.
data.author: Kyle Weston

data.text: Ok, I had a problem very much like this bought a new bike set up to match old bike same saddle and then pain. Went to the doctor and it wasn‚Äôt prostate related. Turns out my problem was Pudendal Neuralgia
data.author: Michael Beuoy

data.text: If the bikes have different geometries your old fit might need adjustment. Also your bike is for gravel racing right? Might need to work on better flexibility. Perineum cut out short nose saddles will relieve a lot of pressure down there.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: I had this when I went from aluminum to carbon. I went from carbon seat rails to titanium or chromoly and it went away. A stiffer bike frame I think was the issue for me.
data.author: Bryan Chappell

data.text: Well... i can say that saddle geometry may be a factor. I had a similar issue when i set up a stationary bike to my exact settings on my bike. I didnt get pain but after 30 minutes i stood up to stretch my legs and noticed my nether regions were entirely numb. The only difference was the saddle shape
data.author: Karl Menace

data.text: I went back to a MTB saddle for my gravel steed and my numb wanker issue went away, a WTB Silverado is what I use and me and my neither region is quite happy
data.author: Kenneth Rieck

data.text: SMP riding forever not an issue
data.author: Patrick J McDonald

data.text: I‚Äôm not being facetious ‚Äú maybe just stand up a lot‚Äù I noticed I do this a lot when I first get a bike or if I know I‚Äôm going to be on a bike like 12 hours I stand up a lot,
data.author: Ed Bridge

data.text: GET RID IF THAT SEAT! NOW! Try Specialized 3D printed saddle. A ridiculous $450 investment, but worth every penny! I now have 3. Happy balls, happy life!

data.text: Don‚Äôt tuck the family jewels under.
data.author: Shiggy Don Person

data.text: Just because the setup is the same as the old bike doesn't mean you're in the same position....different geometry, different position.]\
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: Try using the saddle that you were on before anything else.
data.author: Paul Lindley

data.text: Just take your old saddle and put it on your new one ( fixed )
